conclusion: Need to find temperature in state C given temperature in state A.
State A: volume 6 x 10^-3 m^3, pressure 1 x 10^5 Pa; State C: volume 2 x 10^-3 m^3, pressure 3 x 10^5 Pa.
Recall ideal gas law: PV = nRT; n is constant.
Use combined gas law: P1V1/T1 = P2V2/T2.
Plan to calculate temperature step by step from state A to C.
State A to B: vertical line (constant volume); B to C: straight line decreasing pressure, increasing volume.
State A at (6, 1), B at (6, 2), C at (2, 3) on grid.
Axes labels: pressure in 10^5 Pa (y-axis), volume in 10^-3 m^3 (x-axis).
State B: V_B = 6 x 10^-3 m^3, P_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa.
Convert T_A to Kelvin: T_A = 300.15 K.
State A to B is isochoric: P1/T1 = P2/T2.
State B to C is a general process; use ideal gas law.
Set up ratio: P_B * V_B / T_B = P_C * V_C / T_C.
Solve for T_C: T_C = (P_C * V_C * T_B) / (P_B * V_B).
Convert T_C back to Celsius: T_C ≈ 27°C.
Temperature in state C is the same as in state A: 27°C.
